summary: In this episode, we're introduced to the eccentric scientist Rick Sanchez and his timid grandson Morty Smith. Rick takes Morty on a wild adventure through different dimensions and planets, much to Morty's initial shock and fear. Meanwhile, Morty's parents, Jerry and Beth, are skeptical of Rick's influence on Morty's life. Throughout the episode, we see Rick's disregard for authority and his love for adventure, contrasting with Morty's reluctance to participate in his grandfather's risky escapades. The episode sets the tone for the series, blending sci-fi adventures with dark humor and exploring the dynamic between Rick and Morty

In this episode, Rick gives the family dog, Snuffles, a helmet that enhances his intelligence, leading to the dog gaining sentience and desiring dominance over humans. Meanwhile, Rick creates a dream within a dream to manipulate Morty's teacher into giving him good grades. As Snuffles' intelligence grows, he creates a device that allows him to control humans through their dreams. Rick and Morty enter Snuffles' dream world to stop him, but their plan backfires, resulting in Snuffles deciding to leave Earth with other intelligent dogs to create their own society. The episode explores themes of power dynamics, intelligence, and the consequences of playing god, all while delivering the series' trademark blend of dark humor and sci-fi adventure

In this episode, Rick takes Morty inside the body of a homeless man named Ruben, who Rick had previously employed to oversee his miniature theme park located inside Ruben's body. However, the park's security system fails, putting Morty and Ruben's life at risk as they navigate through Ruben's body. Meanwhile, back at the Smith household, Jerry, Beth, and Summer deal with various Christmas-related issues. Inside Ruben's body, Morty and Rick must overcome obstacles and face off against deadly diseases and malfunctioning attractions to escape. "Anatomy Park" combines gross-out humor with sci-fi elements, as well as exploring themes of family dynamics and the consequences of scientific experimentation

In this episode, Rick and Morty find themselves trapped in a simulation created by alien scammers who are trying to extract an important formula from Rick's mind. Initially unaware they're in a simulation, Rick and Morty go about their daily lives, but Rick eventually catches on and starts messing with the simulation's logic to thwart the aliens' plans. As Rick and Morty navigate the simulated reality, they encounter various absurd scenarios and outsmart the aliens at their own game. The episode is filled with meta-humor and satirical jabs at science fiction tropes, as well as exploring themes of deception and the nature of reality

In this episode, Morty persuades Rick to let him lead an adventure, resulting in the creation of Meeseeks, blue creatures designed to help fulfill a single task. However, things quickly spiral out of control when the Meeseeks struggle with their purpose and become increasingly frustrated. Meanwhile, Jerry, Beth, and Summer deal with their own problems back on Earth. As the chaos ensues, Rick and Morty must find a way to contain the Meeseeks' rampage and restore order. "Meeseeks and Destroy" is known for its humorous exploration of existentialism and the consequences of seeking instant solutions to life's problems

In this episode, Morty asks Rick for a love potion to make his crush, Jessica, fall in love with him. However, the potion backfires and spreads uncontrollably, turning everyone on Earth into grotesque, love-crazed monsters. In an attempt to fix their mistake, Rick and Morty travel to a parallel dimension where they've died and replace their deceased selves. However, they soon discover that they've entered a dimension where their counterparts have successfully cured the love potion, but at a great cost. The episode explores themes of consequence, morality, and the unpredictable nature of science, while delivering its trademark blend of dark humor and sci-fi adventure

In this episode, Morty purchases a sex robot from an intergalactic pawn shop, which ends up being a female Gazorpian named Gwendolyn. Morty learns that Gwendolyn has given birth to his child, leading him to confront the responsibilities of fatherhood. Meanwhile, Rick and Summer explore Gazorpazorp, Gwendolyn's home planet, where they encounter a society of hyper-aggressive male Gazorpazorpians and confront gender stereotypes. As Morty struggles to connect with his alien son, he grapples with the complexities of parenthood. The episode humorously explores themes of gender, parenthood, and cultural differences, while delivering the series' signature blend of satire and sci-fi adventure

In this episode, Rick installs interdimensional cable television in the Smith household, allowing the family to watch shows from alternate realities. Meanwhile, Jerry, Beth, and Summer struggle with their own personal issues while flipping through the channels. As they watch bizarre and absurd programming from different dimensions, they confront the uncertainties of their own lives and relationships. The episode features improvised segments and meta-humor, as well as exploring themes of existentialism and the nature of reality

In this episode, Rick opens a store named "Needful Things" in the town, offering cursed items to unsuspecting customers. Meanwhile, Morty tries to impress a girl named Jessica by purchasing a pair of cursed sneakers that make him incredibly athletic but also possess him with an insatiable desire to kill. As the chaos unfolds, Jerry tries to bond with Rick, unaware of his grandfather's true intentions. The episode explores themes of temptation, consequence, and the dark side of desire, while delivering the series' trademark blend of dark humor and social commentary

In this episode, Rick and Morty are framed for numerous crimes committed across the multiverse by a group of alternate Ricks led by the "Evil" Rick. As they navigate through the multiverse to clear their names, they encounter different versions of themselves and discover a conspiracy involving the Council of Ricks. Meanwhile, the rest of the Smith family deals with their own issues, unaware of Rick and Morty's predicament. The episode delves into themes of identity, morality, and the complexities of the multiverse, while showcasing the series' signature blend of dark humor and sci-fi adventure

In "Ricksy Business", Rick and Morty throw a house party while Jerry and Beth are away on a Titanic-themed getaway to rekindle their marriage. The party quickly spirals out of control as various characters from different dimensions and planets show up. Meanwhile, Summer tries to fit in with her high school peers by throwing her own party, but things take a chaotic turn when a giant spaceship crashes into the backyard. Amidst the mayhem, Rick's portal gun gets stolen, leading to a frantic search to retrieve it. The episode explores themes of teenage rebellion, family dynamics, and the consequences of Rick's irresponsible behavior, all wrapped in the series' trademark humor and sci-fi antics

In this episode titled "A Rickle in Time", Rick, Morty, and Summer must deal with the consequences of freezing time for six months. However, their reckless actions cause time to fracture into multiple realities, each progressing at a different pace. As they try to fix the timeline, they encounter various versions of themselves and face existential dilemmas. Amidst the chaos, Jerry struggles with his newfound authority in the family. The episode is a mind-bending adventure that delves into themes of time, consequence, and the complexities of existence, all while delivering the series' signature blend of humor and sci-fi absurdity

In this episode, Rick takes Morty on a trip to a space arcade where Morty decides to save a stranded creature from being euthanized. Meanwhile, Jerry and Beth go to an intergalactic resort to work on their marriage, leaving Summer with Rick. As Morty attempts to save the stranded creature, Rick sells a gun to an assassin named Krombopulos Michael. Morty becomes conflicted about the consequences of his actions, leading to a series of moral dilemmas and unexpected twists. The episode explores themes of morality, responsibility, and the consequences of one's choices, all while delivering the series' trademark humor and sci-fi adventure

In this episode, Rick reunites with his former lover, Unity, a hive mind entity capable of controlling entire planets. As Rick spends time with Unity, Morty and Summer explore the planet, discovering the disturbing effects of Unity's influence on its inhabitants. Meanwhile, back on Earth, Beth and Jerry struggle with their own marital issues. As the episode unfolds, Rick is forced to confront the toxic nature of his relationship with Unity and the consequences of his actions. "Auto Erotic Assimilation" delves into themes of love, addiction, and the complexity of relationships, all while delivering the series' trademark blend of dark humor and emotional depth

In this episode, the Smith family discovers that their house has been infiltrated by parasitic alien creatures that implant false memories into their minds. These parasites disguise themselves as beloved family members and friends, leading to chaos and confusion as the family struggles to identify the real from the fake. Rick devises a plan to eliminate the parasites by recalling only genuine memories, but the situation becomes increasingly complicated as the parasites continue to multiply and deceive. Through a series of absurd and humorous scenarios, the family must work together to rid themselves of the parasites and restore their sanity. "Total Rickall" is a clever and entertaining exploration of trust, identity, and the nature of memory, infused with the series' trademark wit and inventiveness

In this episode, Earth is threatened by the arrival of giant alien heads known as Cromulons, who demand a live performance of a catchy song or they will destroy the planet. Rick and Morty embark on a mission to save Earth by participating in a televised musical competition, while the rest of the Smith family deals with the chaos and panic ensuing from the alien threat. As the pressure mounts, Rick and Morty must come up with a winning song to appease the Cromulons and save humanity from annihilation. "Get Schwifty" is a hilarious and surreal adventure that satirizes pop culture and reality television while delivering the series' signature blend of absurdity and social commentary

In this episode, Rick and Morty journey inside Rick's car battery to fix a problem causing it to malfunction. Within the battery, they discover a miniature universe Rick created to power his car, inhabited by intelligent lifeforms. Meanwhile, Summer and Rick's ship AI, named "Summer's" voice, engage in a series of misadventures on Earth. As Rick and Morty navigate the complexities of the microverse, they encounter a power struggle between the universe's inhabitants and the dictator-like figure in charge. The episode delves into themes of power dynamics, ethical responsibility, and the consequences of playing god, all while delivering the series' signature blend of dark humor and sci-fi adventure

In the seventh episode of Season 2 of Rick and Morty, titled "Big Trouble in Little Sanchez", Rick transfers his consciousness into a younger clone of himself known as "Tiny Rick" to infiltrate Morty and Summer's high school. As Tiny Rick, he tries to blend in with his grandchildren's social circle while secretly working on a solution to his problem. However, Morty and Summer become increasingly concerned about Tiny Rick's behavior, leading to a confrontation about his true identity and intentions. Meanwhile, Beth and Jerry attend couples therapy with a bizarre alien therapist. "Big Trouble in Little Sanchez" explores themes of identity, aging, and the complexities of family dynamics, all while delivering the series' trademark blend of humor and introspection

In this episode, the Smith family once again tunes into interdimensional cable television. This time, Rick installs a cable box that shows programming from alternate realities, leading to a series of bizarre and unpredictable shows and commercials. As they watch the various channels, the family members react to the strange and often absurd content, providing commentary and engaging in humorous interactions. The episode is a sequel to the Season 1 episode "Rixty Minutes" and features improvised segments and meta-humor, offering a glimpse into the infinite possibilities of the multiverse while showcasing the series' trademark blend of wit and surrealism

In this episode, Rick and Morty visit a planet that is in the midst of an annual purge, where all crime is legal for a 12-hour period. Initially intending to simply refuel the spaceship, Rick and Morty become embroiled in the chaos of the purge when they encounter a young girl in need of help. As they navigate the violent and lawless streets, they confront their own morality and the consequences of their actions. Meanwhile, Summer and Jerry bond over their shared experiences back on Earth. "Look Who's Purging Now" is a darkly humorous exploration of societal violence and the human condition, infused with the series' trademark wit and satire

In the last episode of Season 2, Rick is invited to the wedding of his close friend Birdperson, where he introduces the family to his new girlfriend, Tammy. However, the wedding takes a dark turn when it is revealed that Tammy is an undercover agent for the Galactic Federation, leading to a chaotic showdown. Rick, Morty, and the rest of the family find themselves on the run, forced to flee to a new dimension to escape capture. As they settle into their new lives, they grapple with the consequences of their actions and the uncertainty of their future. "The Wedding Squanchers" is a thrilling conclusion to the second season, packed with action, emotion, and unexpected twists, while continuing to explore the complexities of the Smith family dynamic

In the first episode of Season 3 of Rick and Morty, titled "The Rickshank Rickdemption", Rick Sanchez breaks out of Galactic Federation prison and returns to Earth, revealing his true motive behind turning himself in at the end of Season 2. Rick hijacks the Galactic Federation's brain-link technology to manipulate the government and dismantle the intergalactic currency, plunging the economy into chaos. Meanwhile, Morty and the rest of the Smith family cope with the fallout of Rick's actions and struggle to adapt to life under Federation rule. "The Rickshank Rickdemption" is a thrilling and inventive episode that sets the tone for the season, exploring themes of power, control, and the consequences of Rick's genius

In this episode, Rick takes Morty on an adventure to a dimension inhabited by sentient gas clouds, where Morty becomes infatuated with one named Armothy. Meanwhile, Summer discovers Rick's secret underground lair and inadvertently releases a horde of mutated creatures called "Cronenbergs" into their dimension. As chaos ensues, Rick, Morty, and Summer must work together to contain the Cronenbergs and find a way to restore their world to normalcy. "Rickmurai Jack" is a wild and inventive episode that blends humor, action, and emotional depth, while further exploring the dynamic between the Smith family and the consequences of Rick's reckless actions

In this episode, Rick turns himself into a pickle to avoid attending a family therapy session with Beth, Morty, and Summer. Stranded as a pickle, Rick must use his intellect and resourcefulness to survive in a hostile environment. Meanwhile, back at the therapy session, the family confronts their unresolved issues and struggles with Rick's absence. As Rick navigates his perilous situation as a pickle, he faces unexpected challenges and gains newfound insights into his relationships with his family. "Pickle Rick" is a darkly comedic and action-packed episode that delves into themes of identity, family dynamics, and the lengths one will go to avoid confronting their problems

In the fourth episode of Season 3, Rick and Morty are recruited by the Vindicators, a superhero team, to help them defeat their arch-nemesis, Worldender. However, Rick, feeling slighted by the Vindicators' arrogance, gets drunk and sabotages their mission. As the Vindicators face deadly challenges, Morty must confront Rick's destructive behavior and question the nature of heroism. The episode is a satirical take on superhero tropes and explores themes of ego, morality, and the consequences of unchecked power, all while delivering the series' trademark blend of humor and existentialism

In this episode, Rick takes Jerry on an adventure to a resort inside a living being's internal organs to cheer him up after Beth files for divorce. However, their trip takes a dangerous turn when Jerry's attempts to get Rick killed by an assassin backfire, leading to chaos and introspection. Meanwhile, back on Earth, Summer deals with her own issues related to her parents' divorce. As the episode unfolds, Rick and Jerry confront their strained relationship and the complexities of family dynamics. "The Whirly Dirly Conspiracy" is a hilarious and thought-provoking episode that explores themes of betrayal, forgiveness, and the lengths one will go to maintain relationships

In this episode, Rick and Morty use a machine to remove their toxic traits, which manifest as separate beings. The purified versions of Rick and Morty go on a relaxation spree, while the toxic versions wreak havoc. However, they soon realize that both their purified and toxic traits are essential parts of who they are. The episode explores themes of self-acceptance, the duality of human nature, and the importance of embracing one's flaws

In the seventh episode of Season 3 of Rick and Morty, titled "The Ricklantis Mixup" (also known as "Tales from the Citadel"), the episode primarily focuses on the lives of various Ricks and Mortys living in the Citadel, a society built by infinite versions of Rick. The episode presents multiple interconnected storylines, showcasing the diverse experiences and struggles of different Ricks and Mortys within the Citadel. From a rookie cop Morty to a disillusioned factory worker Rick, the episode offers a glimpse into the complex social structure and power dynamics of the Citadel. "The Ricklantis Mixup" is a captivating exploration of identity, inequality, and the consequences of living in a society shaped by infinite versions of oneself

In this episode, Morty discovers that Rick has been erasing his memories of traumatic or disturbing experiences. Morty is initially upset by this revelation and demands to see all the memories Rick has removed. As Morty revisits these forgotten moments, he uncovers a series of bizarre and unsettling events, including encounters with aliens, alternate dimensions, and even Rick's own mistakes. The episode delves into themes of memory, perception, and the consequences of knowledge, while showcasing the complex and often tumultuous relationship between Rick and Morty

In this episode, Beth becomes conflicted about her identity and whether she's truly happy with her life. Seeking clarity, she turns to Rick for guidance, leading him to offer her the opportunity to create a perfect alternate dimension where she can live out her wildest fantasies. As Beth explores this new reality, she confronts her inner demons and the consequences of her actions. Meanwhile, back in the original dimension, Morty and Summer deal with their own personal struggles and come to terms with their mother's decision. "The ABC's of Beth" is a thought-provoking exploration of identity, choice, and the complexities of family relationships, all while delivering the series' trademark blend of humor and existentialism

In this episode, Rick and Morty face off against the President of the United States after Rick challenges him to a high-stakes showdown. Meanwhile, Summer tries to navigate her own issues and assert her independence within the family dynamic. As tensions escalate between Rick and the President, they engage in a series of increasingly absurd and over-the-top confrontations. The episode is a wild and action-packed conclusion to the season, packed with humor, satire, and unexpected twists, while continuing to explore the complexities of the Smith family and Rick's place in the multiverse

In the first episode of Season 4 of Rick and Morty, titled "Edge of Tomorty: Rick Die Rickpeat", Morty obtains a death crystal that shows him visions of potential deaths, leading him to become obsessed with shaping his future. Meanwhile, Rick embarks on a mission to acquire a powerful isotope that can extend his life indefinitely. As Morty's obsession with his own mortality grows, he and Rick find themselves caught in a series of dangerous and surreal situations. The episode explores themes of fate, mortality, and the consequences of chasing immortality, all while delivering the series' trademark blend of humor and sci-fi adventure

In this episode, Jerry embarks on a quest to find out who used his private restroom, leading him to encounter a mysterious entity named "Tony." Meanwhile, Rick becomes emotionally attached to a secret project he's been working on, which involves creating a private paradise for himself. As Jerry's investigation leads to unexpected revelations, Rick's obsession with his project reaches a breaking point, forcing him to confront his own vulnerabilities. The episode explores themes of privacy, loneliness, and the complexities of interpersonal relationships, all while delivering the series' trademark blend of humor and introspection

In this episode, Rick recruits Morty, along with a ragtag group of strangers, to pull off an elaborate heist on an alien artifact. As the group navigates through a series of increasingly absurd and convoluted plans, tensions rise and loyalties are tested. Meanwhile, Summer deals with her own personal struggles back on Earth. The episode is a humorous and satirical take on the heist genre, poking fun at clichés and tropes while delivering the series' trademark blend of wit and irreverence

In this episode, Morty adopts a mysterious dragon while Rick indulges in a bizarre adventure involving an enigmatic crystal. As Morty's bond with the dragon deepens, he becomes entangled in a fantastical journey filled with mythical creatures and magical realms. Meanwhile, Rick's pursuit of the crystal leads him to confront his own desires and insecurities. The episode is a whimsical and surreal exploration of friendship, fantasy, and the absurdity of existence, all while delivering the series' trademark blend of humor and existentialism

In this episode, Morty accidentally kills a space snake while on a mission with Rick, triggering a chain of events that leads to the evolution of the snake species into a highly intelligent and vengeful race. As the space snakes seek retribution against humanity, Rick and Morty must find a way to prevent an all-out war while navigating through time paradoxes and alternate timelines. The episode is a clever and action-packed exploration of the consequences of seemingly insignificant actions, wrapped in the series' trademark blend of humor and sci-fi adventure

In this episode, Rick and Morty find themselves trapped aboard a mysterious train with a diverse cast of characters. As they journey through the train's surreal and ever-changing compartments, they encounter bizarre scenarios and metafictional elements that blur the lines between reality and fiction. Meanwhile, the story is intercut with scenes of a meta-narrative discussion between a story train conductor and a story lord, adding layers of complexity to the episode's narrative. "Never Ricking Morty" is a mind-bending and self-referential exploration of storytelling, creativity, and the nature of reality, all while delivering the series' trademark blend of humor and existentialism

Rick and Morty embark on an adventure to retrieve space crystals from a hive mind alien species. However, Morty is outraged by Rick's disregard for the aliens' lives and decides to save one of them. Meanwhile, Summer and Beth deal with their own existential crises and confrontations with alien parasites. As the episode unfolds, the family faces the consequences of their actions and grapples with questions of morality and identity. "Promortyus" is a thought-provoking exploration of empathy, individuality, and the complexities of intergalactic relationships, all while delivering the series' trademark blend of humor and social commentary

In this episode, Morty becomes frustrated with Rick's reckless disregard for consequences and demands a safer adventure. In response, Rick creates a device that allows Morty to reset reality whenever he wants, leading Morty to explore various scenarios and consequences without fear. However, Morty's abuse of the device eventually leads to unforeseen and catastrophic consequences, forcing him to confront the reality of his choices. The episode is a clever and introspective exploration of accountability, consequence, and the nature of free will, all while delivering the series' trademark blend of humor and existentialism

In this episode, Rick and Morty encounter a civilization ruled by a powerful alien named "Glootie." Meanwhile, back on Earth, Summer tries to convince her parents, Jerry and Beth, to let her have a pet snake. As Rick and Morty become embroiled in the affairs of the alien civilization, they must navigate political intrigue and family dynamics while confronting their own moral dilemmas. The episode is a humorous and thought-provoking exploration of power dynamics, parenthood, and the complexities of intergalactic relationships, all while delivering the series' trademark blend of satire and sci-fi adventure

In the tenth and final episode of Season 4 of Rick and Morty, titled "Star Mort Rickturn of the Jerri", the Smith family faces off against Tammy and the Galactic Federation in a high-stakes showdown. Meanwhile, Rick confronts his long-lost friend turned nemesis, Phoenixperson, in a battle that tests the limits of their abilities and their relationship. As the conflict escalates, the family must come together to overcome their adversaries and protect their loved ones. The episode is a thrilling conclusion to the season, packed with action, humor, and emotional moments, while continuing to explore the complexities of the Smith family dynamic and Rick's place in the multiverse

In the first episode of Season 5 of Rick and Morty, titled "Mort Dinner Rick Andre", Morty invites his classmate Jessica to a dinner with Rick and the family, hoping to impress her. However, things take a bizarre turn when Rick reveals that he has created a machine that can duplicate any object, leading to a series of chaotic and surreal events. As the duplicates multiply and wreak havoc, Morty must navigate through the chaos and confront his own insecurities. The episode is a hilarious and inventive exploration of identity, desire, and the consequences of unchecked ambition, all while delivering the series' trademark blend of humor and sci-fi adventure

In this episode, Rick introduces Morty to a device called the "Go-Tron Ferret", which allows them to travel to alternate dimensions. However, their trip takes a chaotic turn when they encounter numerous versions of themselves from parallel universes, each engaged in their own adventures. As they navigate through the multiverse, they must confront their doppelgängers and unravel the mysteries of their existence. Meanwhile, back on Earth, the Smith family deals with their own challenges as they are caught in the crossfire of the interdimensional chaos. The episode is a wild and inventive exploration of identity, reality, and the consequences of playing god, all while delivering the series' trademark blend of humor and existentialism

In this episode, Rick and Morty find themselves entangled in a complex ecological conspiracy when they visit a planet inhabited by sentient ocean creatures. As they investigate the mysterious disappearance of a scientist, they uncover a plot that threatens the delicate balance of the planet's ecosystem. Meanwhile, Summer and Morty's pet horse, Snuffles, embark on their own adventure back on Earth. The episode is a thrilling and thought-provoking exploration of environmentalism, activism, and the consequences of human intervention, all while delivering the series' trademark blend of humor and social commentary

In this fourth episode of Season 5, Rick and Morty join forces with a group of superheroes known as the "Vindicators" to combat a deadly threat posed by parasitic aliens. As they work together to save the world, tensions rise among the Vindicators and secrets are revealed, forcing Rick and Morty to confront their own vulnerabilities and insecurities. Meanwhile, Summer and Jerry deal with their own personal struggles as they navigate through the chaos. The episode is a thrilling and action-packed adventure that explores themes of heroism, teamwork, and the complexities of power dynamics, all while delivering the series' trademark blend of humor and existentialism

In this episode, Morty's attempt to impress a girl leads to unexpected consequences when he inadvertently becomes involved in a conflict between two alien species. Meanwhile, Rick finds himself in a precarious situation after making a bet with the President of the United States. As Morty tries to navigate through the chaos and save the day, he learns valuable lessons about responsibility and the consequences of his actions. The episode is a humorous and action-packed adventure that explores themes of loyalty, friendship, and the complexities of intergalactic diplomacy, all while delivering the series' trademark blend of wit and irreverence

In this episode, the Smith family celebrates Thanksgiving with a twist when Rick decides to manipulate the holiday for his own amusement. As the family gathers for dinner, tensions rise and secrets are revealed, leading to chaos and introspection. Meanwhile, Rick and Morty embark on a surreal adventure that tests their bond and challenges their perceptions of reality. The episode is a humorous and satirical exploration of family dynamics, tradition, and the absurdity of holiday celebrations, all while delivering the series' trademark blend of humor and social commentary

In this episode, Rick and Summer join forces with other alternate versions of themselves from different dimensions to create a giant robot, the "Gotron", in order to combat a giant monster threatening Earth. Meanwhile, Jerry experiences an existential crisis as he grapples with his role within the family and his feelings of inadequacy. As the family navigates through their respective challenges, they must confront their own insecurities and work together to save the world. The episode is a thrilling and action-packed adventure that explores themes of teamwork, self-discovery, and the complexities of family dynamics, all while delivering the series' trademark blend of humor and sci-fi escapades

In this episode, Morty becomes frustrated with Rick's disregard for his well-being and decides to erase all memories of their adventures together. However, the memory-erasing process goes awry, leading Morty to confront his own inner demons and insecurities. Meanwhile, Rick embarks on a journey into Morty's subconscious to retrieve the lost memories and repair their fractured relationship. The episode is a surreal and introspective exploration of memory, identity, and the complexities of the bond between Rick and Morty, all while delivering the series' trademark blend of humor and existentialism

In this ninth episode of Season 5, Rick and Morty embark on a mission to rescue Jessica from an alternate dimension where she has been trapped by an evil Morty. However, their rescue mission takes an unexpected turn when they encounter versions of themselves from different dimensions, leading to chaos and confusion. Meanwhile, back on Earth, the rest of the Smith family deals with their own personal issues and confrontations. The episode is a thrilling and action-packed adventure that explores themes of friendship, loyalty, and the consequences of one's actions, all while delivering the series' trademark blend of humor and sci-fi hijinks

In the tenth and final episode of Rick and Morty, titled "Rickmurai Jack", Rick and Morty embark on a surreal and epic adventure to confront their greatest foe yet. As they face off against a formidable enemy, they must confront their own fears and insecurities, ultimately leading to a climactic showdown that will determine the fate of the multiverse. Meanwhile, back on Earth, the rest of the Smith family grapples with their own personal struggles and dilemmas. The episode is a thrilling and action-packed conclusion to the season, packed with humor, emotion, and unexpected twists, while continuing to explore the complexities of the Smith family dynamic and Rick's place in the multiverse
